Rocket Internet SE: Special Items Weigh on Results for the First Half of 2016
- Consolidated loss of EUR 617 million in the first half of 2016
- First half 2016 results negatively impacted by special items, in particular at GFG
Berlin, Germany, September 1, 2016 - Special items, in particular due to impairments at Global Fashion Group S.A. ("GFG"), weighed on the results of Rocket Internet SE ("Rocket Internet" or the "Company") in the first half of 2016. As a result of the last funding round for GFG, which was announced in April 2016 and which closed in July 2016, GFG wrote-off goodwill and intangible assets. GFG contributed negative EUR 383 million to the Rocket Internet's first half year results. The result was further impacted by special items such as impairments, fair value adjustments and - to a lesser extent - positive special items. Overall, the consolidated loss for the first half of 2016 was EUR 617 million.
As a result of deconsolidation effects, group revenues in the first half of 2016 decreased to EUR 29 million compared to EUR 71 million in first half of 2015.
"Despite these special items, we remain committed to our goals", says Oliver Samwer, CEO Rocket Internet. "We still expect at least three of our selected portfolio companies to turn profitable by the end of 2017, and that the aggregate EBITDA losses of the selected portfolio companies will have peaked in 2015. "
Rocket Internet will report detailed results for the first half of 2016 on September 22, 2016.

BE

11:15 am
BE

One of our biggest concerns with RKET was its overconfident valuation methodology, LPV, which saw its valuation of one of the largest assets in which it has a stake, GFG, cut from €3.0bn to €1.0bn on 27 April. Despite the macro environment being out of its control, the more conservative valuation methodology at KINV meant its valuation only reduced by 38%, versus 66% at RKET.

BE

Yes, losing €2bn from a €3bn company in five months with no significant changes to operations in that period will raise a couple of questions about your methodology.

BE

Last heard, 1Q16 results, 31 May, for its selected portfolio companies:
1. Aggregate revenue +34% to €531m, biggest gainer HelloFresh +211.3% to €141m;
2. EBITDA loss reduced by -23% to -€137m, or improvement in aggregate margin
of +18.3ppts. Biggest winners Westwing and Dafiti with an average increase in
margin of +25ppts YoY, or a reduction in EBITDA loss of €12m and €9m;
3. Net cash of €1.3bn for Rocket Internet as at the end of April 2016; and
4. April 2016 LPV of €40 per share implies a 44% discount. Using our more
conservative 'Kinnevik'd' method, NAV goes to €29, 23% discount, at the time.

11:16 am
BE

Why are we writing today? A surprise trading update from the company last night, a
profit warning for its H116 ... full details still out 22 Sept as previously expected:
1. Results impacted by the last funding round for GFG, which closed in July;
2. GFG wrote-off goodwill and intangible assets;
3. GFG contributed -€383m to RKET's H116 results; and
4. Overall, the consolidated loss for RKET's H116 was -€617m, after 'further impacted
by special items such as impairments, fair value adjustments'

BE

The strategic pivot into ‘food and groceries’, jolted? RKET’s success with HelloFresh
was backed up by an investment into online takeaway food; the Delivery Hero group, a
material investment c.€900m across 2015. However, two of the assets that it acquired in
February 2015 for c.€130m, were sold to Just Eat only a year later for €125m, along with
two foodpanda assets, and presumably after a year's worth of investment too.
We compare RKET with Kinnevik. Kinnevik, the closest peer and still c.15% of RKET's
portfolio overlaps. Kinnevik is less promotional, more balanced, and measurably more
conservative. Kinnevik values its stakes in the overlapping businesses at a c.30% discount to
the comparable RKET LPV. We see the real results of this today.

BE

Yep.

11:17 am

You should also read Neil Campling on Rocket

11:17 am
PM

Northern Trust

PM

Rocket’s mission is to become the world’s largest Internet Platform outside the United States and China. It would appear to us that that might take some time given the H1 2016 statement this morning. Rocket has announced that H1 2016 will record a consolidated loss of EUR617M. GFG contributed negative EUR383M to Rocket’s first half results, but there are also other impacts which are not specified at this time other than a broad mention of special items such as impairments and fair value adjustments. The result is a consolidated loss for the first half of 2016 of -EUR617M. In addition group revenues, as a result of deconsolidation effects, fell c.60% YoY to EUR29M in 1H16 from EUR71M in 1H15. We will have to wait until 22 September to get the full detailed results.

GFG’s carried value on Rocket Internet’s LPV had to be significantly reduced at the time of the last funding round (announced April 2016 and completed in July). At the last recorded LPV (the KPI Rocket Internet themselves focus on) group LPV was recorded at EUR5.32B as of April 2016. Since this time, Rocket companies outside of GFG have been the subject of either capital raising (Delivery Hero) or carried value reductions in co-investor reports (e.g. Home24). In the example of Delivery Hero, there has been no financial disclosure on the valuation at the time of the high two-digit million Euro capital raise (announced 18th August). In the example of Home24, Kinnevik reduced the carried valuation of Home 24 by 88% between December 2015 and June 2016. In contrast Rocket has maintained the valuation of Home24 in April 2016 (the last released LPV) from that provided in September 2015.

PM

We have made adjustments to our estimates of Rocket companies LPVs in light of Unicorn down-rounds, business challenges and co-investor mark to market transactions. Relative to Rocket’s owned carried valuations we have reduced Hello Fresh, Delivery Hero, Jumia and Linio carried valuations by 30%, reduced Food Panda carried valuation by 50% owing to tough trading conditions and adjusted West Wing and Home 24 on a mark-to-market basis in line with co-investor Kinnevik valuations. We have also reduced the fair value of the new business and investment by 25% to reflect the more challenging conditions of companies Easy Taxi (exiting Asia and Africa) and the Latin American Internet Group which has a stake in GFG. We don’t feel these actions are overly aggressive given VC backed private technology company valuations have fallen by an average of 30-50% in 2016 (Source: CBInsights). The result of these actions produces a current Rocket group LPV of EUR3.59B, which is a full 33% below the EUR5.32B Group LPV Rocket has most recently reported (April 2016).

We expect significant downward pressure on Rocket's carried LPV which is their own preferred KPI. Such, in turn, could also risk Rocket's ability to IPO portfolio companies which is a key business strategy to unlock value for shareholders. Add in weak business momentum, opaque funding structures and the rising risk of down rounds in portfolio companies we remain sellers of Rocket Internet.

Importantly, the company reiterated its guidance in relation to its Proven
Winners, namely that it continues to expect at least three portfolio companies
to turn profitable by the end of 2017, and that the aggregate EBITDA losses of
the selected portfolio companies will have peaked in 2015. We think it is
important to note that there is no connection between consolidated losses
reported for the group (which includes writedowns, value adjustments,
deconsolidation and other accounting effects, and does not reflect the operating
cash flows) and EBITDA losses of Rocket’s portfolio companies (which reflect
the operational performance and cash flows).

11:30 am
BE

One is always very nervous publishing new documents that have involved weeks of work ahead of a big payrolls report that could be a big market mover. However that's where we stand and today has the potential in theory to reprice Fed September rate hike expectations nearer to or even above 50% (34% currently but down from 42% last Friday), especially if we print notably above 200k. Remember that just after the Brexit vote you had to go out to the end of 2017 to see the first Fed hike being priced. Although trying to predict a fairly random number is a mugs game I would take the low side of the 180k consensus today (DB at 160k). A lot of people were a bit nervous about the seasonal distortion in last month's strong report and as DB's Joe LaVorgna pointed out earlier this week, over the last 5 years the initially-reported August nonfarm payroll gains has consistently disappointed consensus and by an average of 52k.
In today's PDF we show the average payroll for each month since January 2010. As the graph shows August has tended to be a weaker month relative to the rest of the year. Indeed since the start of the sample the average monthly payrolls reading is +186k while the average August reading is just +150k (which is the joint lowest with July). Although July's number went against this trend, will both July and August buck their seasonal trend?

PM

(Sos -- http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz4IuRRoVLE )

BE

UBS provides a very brief summary, as is its style .....

BE

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Volumes were up 20% y/y in FY16 (in line) and ASP up 8% leading to revenues of
£635m (UBSe £622m). Underlying EBIT margin in H2 was guided for 100bps
improvement vs H1 vs UBSe at +570bps leading to a PTP of +19% y/y in FY16
(UBSe/consensus +30%).
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Operating margin was hampered by the level of incentives used in H2 in light of
more challenging trading conditions post the EU Referendum, leading to a margin miss.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: McCarthy & Stone acknowledged some weakness in the secondary market, leading
to slower sales rates and higher cancellations. Volume growth of 15% in FY17E could
be at risk.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: We expect a negative market reaction, with a 10% miss at the PTP vs consensus and
given the more challenging trading conditions in the secondary market.

BE

.... having previously been sellers, I think.

11:34 am
BE

Jefferies fills out with a bit more detail.

BE

Today's trading update is a clear indication (were one needed) of the power of Help to Buy and of how strongly the first-hand market is linked to the second-hand one.

BE

However, near-term and long-term fundamentals remain strong. We saw
estimate cuts in the region of 20%-30% across the UK estate agents for 2016E and 2017E
at the interim stage; however, as yet, guidance has not changed for 2017 for McCarthy &
Stone. We are not suggesting there are no downside risks, but rather the demand for agerelated
homes is more inelastic than that of the market as whole; the coming together of
aspiration and need underpins demand, in our view. Typically customers of McCarthy need
to sell their home in order to move. Estate agents talk of a shortage of supply of family
homes, mortgages are readily available (we counted 1254 mortgage products currently on
sale for house purchase and more than 300 at 90% LTV) and mortgage rates are low and
falling (in July the average rate on new mortgages was 2.31%); the demand supply balance
is therefore in the downsizer's favour.

11:35 am
BE

Sales rates are promising and linked to site openings. We estimate that sales rates
are currently in mid-50s, off a June/July low of low-40s, and at a level commensurate with
our current FY2017 volume estimate of 2650. Site openings, at five, were much lower in Q4
16 than the 10 in Q4 15. There are 13 planned openings in Q1 17 compared with 16 in Q1
16, and sales are typically front-end loaded.
Being prepared. McCarthy & Stone has a detailed cyclicality play book as outlined in
pages 62-64 of our note Building on Age and Experience and we see the first fruits of this in
today's trading update: land spend is tempered and cash is being conserved.
It's not over till the old lady sings. It is clear that today's trading update contains
some disappointing news, and the share price is likely, in our view, to come under pressure
between now and the full-year results (15 November), which may offer attractive entry
points for those looking at the longer-term fundamentals rather than the shorter jitters.

PM

(Limey -- last portfolio valuation)

PM

(ie -- valuation last time money was raised)

11:36 am
BE

And Deutsche ..................

BE

Against the strong trading updates from volume peers in the past weeks, McCarthy & Stone’s miss of DBs FY 16 PBT ests and the lower order book has the potential to disappoint. However with signs of sales returning to ‘normal’ in August, we are comfortable the moderate downside assumptions on which are forecasts are based remain very conservative. With a share price down 15% (FTSE350 +6%) since the Brexit vote McCarthy & Stone now trades at just over 1.5x 2017 calendarised NTAV. For a group showing sector leading profit growth, a greater conditionality of its land buying and scope for top quartile ROCE we believe this is inexpensive, although Brexit concerns continue to impact.

BE

1) Adj PBT +19% YoY, but weaker than DB ests reflecting higher incentives. While McCarthy’s update demonstrates that even with Brexit uncertainty it can meet its ambitious completions target (+20%) and that guidance on price has been conservative, the impact of the 1-3ppt pick up in incentives on H1 16 (to 6-8%, but flat on FY 15) resulted in adj PBT while up 19% YoY being 6% below DB ests. ROCE was 20%. 2) Growth strategy on track, but no clear update on targets. YE 16 the group reported higher than expected net cash of £52m reflecting a slow down in land buying (65 sites/2,614 plots vs 90 last year). However with terms agreed on 1900 plots (vs 500 last year) we believe its growth strategy remains on track. Mgmt indicates build starts have slowed reflecting Brexit caution but that it has started on all sites for FY 17 completion. As such, the group indicates its ability to reach its 15% volume target for FY 17 will depend on its customer demand (DBe are conservative reflecting just +5%). 3) Order book shows June/July weakness, but August appears closer to normal. Reflecting a weak June/July McCarthy reported its forward order book -13% YoY to £114m. Post Brexit the elderly customer base appears to have reacted more cautiously: cancellation rates up and a dip in selling rates– although the latter likely impacted by the limited new site releases over the summer (5 sites June-Aug). However mgmt indicates positive signs of improvement –13 site launches Sep- Oct, August gross selling rates meaningfully up on July as well as up YoY, cancellation rates returning to the 15-20% norm, August enquiries up a touch MoM, web hits up 1/3, and newly qualified visitors while up a little on the previous months also up on 9m 16.

Ibstock’s legacy shareholder, Bain Capital, has sold 21% of its shareholding (40.5m shares) in the group. This equates to 10% of Ibstock’s share capital and has reduced Bain’s shareholding in the group to 37%. The placing price is 175p per share, a near 6% discount to the most recent close (186p). The backdrop to the disposal is the recent recovery in the Ibstock share price towards its 190p IPO level. We recently initiated coverage on Ibstock with an ‘Outperform’ rating. We believe the stock offers good quality exposure to what remains a structurally attractive UK brick market, despite near-term uncertainty, along with room for better returns and margins from its US operation. Our current price target is 207p.

PM

See ASOS paid out 20m to settle these trade mark disputes?

PM

The Board of ASOS Plc ("ASOS") announces that it has reached a global settlement regarding trade mark infringement disputes with high-performance cycle wear manufacturer Assos of Switzerland GmbH ("Assos"), and German menswear retailer, Anson's Herrenhaus KG ("Anson's"). The disputes have resulted in several cases being heard in court, as well as multiple trade mark registry actions around the world.

Agreements have been entered into whereby ASOS is to pay a total of £20.2 million in cash, in a full, final and global settlement of all outstanding litigation with each of Assos and Anson's, securing a comprehensive co-existence for all parties.

BE

PM

For almost three years now asos PLC and the menswear chain Anson’s Herrenhaus KG
have been engaged in a bitter struggle over the name ASOS. Anson's consider that the
name ASOS, originally an abbreviation for "As seen on screen", could be confused with
the brand ANSON'S.

BE

Exane's retail team's been on the call. They can explain, hopefully better than us.

12:00 pm
PM

http://www.boehmer...112013_English.pdf

BE

‘Assos’ and ‘Anson’s’ had been trading before the ASOS brand had launched in 2002. This infringement dispute has been on-going since 2011/12, which ASOS had been defending successfully. As such, the dispute had been recognised as a contingent liability and no provision had been recognised. However, there still remains ongoing court cases globally, and so ASOS has agreed to make a settlement on the following basis:

(1) Market risk. Legal cases continue in France, Germany and the US – all key markets for ASOS. Whilst ASOS has successfully defended itself until now, there was no certainty they would be successful in these markets. Losing a case in either of these markets would force ASOS to rebrand, which was a significant risk that ASOS has eliminated.
(2) Sportswear category. Given Assos’ focus in sportswear, ASOS has until now refrained from moving into the sportswear / athleisure category to avoid aggravating the dispute. This has limited the opportunity for ASOS in own-brand and also with some 3rd party brands. Settling the dispute now gives ASOS the flexibility to extend into these categories globally.
(3) Resource. ASOS had been successfully defending the dispute for a number of years, but this was still consuming resource within the business and was a management distraction.

BE

- The cash payment of £20.2m will be recognised as an exceptional item and cash outflow in FY16
- Still expect the year end cash balance to be higher than H1 position of £136m (We forecast FY16 £150m net cash before this settlement)
- The settlement does not change any plans in investment, and there is no changes to capex guidance.
- There are no other ongoing IP cases which are material to the Group.

Settlement in context
Whilst the £20.2m cash payment is optically large, this looks to be the right commercial decision for the business in the long term. The settlement brings certainty over the end of the dispute and eliminates any further litigation risk in ASOS’ biggest markets. The settlement also opens up the opportunity of moving the ASOS own-brand into the attractive ‘athleisure’ market. With year-end cash still expected to be higher than interim position, ASOS remains in a healthy balance sheet position with the ability to continue investing for long term growth. The settlement is therefore immaterial in this context.
